ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Welcome, Evan, to the Museum of Neurodiversity.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: When Robin was younger, society wasn't as understanding of those with neurodiversities as it is today.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Your goal is to investigate these memories and generate plaques for the individuals in them. Each plaque should include a name, their relationship to Robin, and their role in the exhibit.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Be aware that these memories are fragile and will slightly corrupt with each investigation. Use your Memory Journal (TAB key) to keep track of your findings.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response:
It’s a lot to take in, but you’ll get the hang of it. You can always come back to ask any questions.

Do you have any questions about anything I mentioned?

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: As you move around within a memory, the corruption meter on your screen will increase. This represents the degradation of the memory due to your exploration.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: The memories are fragile and each movement within them causes a bit of corruption. If the corruption meter is full, you’ll need to reset the memory. You can reset the memory by pressing Q.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Remember, we’re not exactly sure how many times we’ll be able to reset the memory before it becomes too corrupted to use, so choose what you investigate wisely.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response:
Changes in the journal will automatically update the plaques. Once you’re satisfied with the answers you find, you may submit them from your journal.
Then your work for the exhibit is done!

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: You can access the Memory Journal by pressing the TAB key. In the journal, you can note down the details of each individual, such as their name, their relationship to Robin, and their role in the exhibit.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: As a volunteer, you’ll be exploring the memories of Robin, a neurodiverse individual, using our Memory Mapping technology.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: The plaques in this exhibit serve as identifiers for the individuals you encounter in Robin’s memories. Each plaque will include the following details: a name, their relationship to the subject, and their role in the exhibit.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: The Memory Journal is designed to help you keep track of the individuals you encounter and their roles in the memories you’ll be exploring.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Our goal is to shed light on the mistreatment they and others like them faced. Robin agreed to share her memories, however, we need more information, and that's where you come in.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: In the context of this exhibit, the roles you assign to the individuals in Robin’s memories are a way to tell a story that aligns with the message of the exhibit.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: Any changes you make in your Memory Journal will be updated to the plaques automatically. This means that as you gather more information and refine your understanding of each individual, the plaques will reflect these updates.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response:
Once you’re satisfied with the answers you find, you may submit them from your journal.
Then your work for the exhibit is done!

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: The plaques will be automatically placed in front of the corresponding individuals in the memory, serving as a guide for visitors to the exhibit.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: You can update the plaques directly from your Memory Journal. Any changes you make in the journal will update the plaques accordingly.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: The roles you assign to individuals in Robin’s memories should not only convey the experiences and challenges faced by Robin, but also highlight the interactions and relationships that shaped her life.

ResponseNodes.Name: ResponseNode
ResponseNodes.Response: These roles aim to deepen visitors’ understanding of Robin’s experiences and the broader context of neurodiversity.
